haven't got the Ming-Mongs![[Doctor Who Magazine]]27429–30[[Marvel Comics]][[Royal Tunbridge Wells|Tunbridge Wells]], Kent0957-9818andVictor Lewis-Smith's "Gay Daleks".cite newsDoctor stuck in a time warphttp://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/newsfeatures/2005/0312/1110452198946.html[[The Irish Times]]Dublin12 March 20053 February 2010ShaneHegartyOccasionally the BBC has used the Daleks to parody other subjects: in 2002,BBC Worldwidepublished theDalek Survival Guide, a parody ofWorst-Case Scenario seriesThe Worst-Case Scenario Survival Handbooks.cite bookRichardsJustinJustin Richards[[Nicholas Briggs]][[Stephen Cole (writer)|Stephen Cole]][[Jacqueline Rayner]][[Mike Tucker]]Ben Dunn (editor)Dalek Survival Guide2002[[BBC Worldwide]]London0-563-48600-7ComedianEddie Izzardhas an extended stand-up routine about Daleks, which was included in his 1993 stand-up show "Live at the Ambassadors".cite newsEddie Izzard: The tough transvestite who can take care of himselfRamptonJames[[The Independent]]23 May 2004http://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/eddie-izzard-the-tough-transvestite-who-can-take-care-of-himself-564108.html3 February 2010LondonThe Daleks made two brief appearances in apantomimeversion ofAladdinat theBirmingham Hippodromewhich starredTorchwoodstarJohn Barrowmanin the lead role.cite newsAladdin @ HippodromeHollyBeaumont-WilkesBBC News28 December 2007http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2007/12/28/aladdin_review_feature.shtml3 February 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20140224182547/http://www.bbc.co.uk/birmingham/content/articles/2007/12/28/aladdin_review_feature.shtml24 February 2014A joke-telling robot, possessing a Dalek-like boom, and loosely modelled after the Dalek, also appeared in theSouth Parkepisode "Funnybot", even spouting out "exterminate".cite webhttp://m.ign.com/articles/1166181South Park: "Funnybot" Review – IGNM.ign.com5 May 201111 October 2011A Dalek can also be seen in the background at timepoints 1:13 and 1:17 in theSam & Maxanimated series episodeThe Trouble With Gary. In theCommunity (TV series)Communityparody ofDoctor WhocalledInspector Spacetime, they are referred to as Blorgons.
article.heading: Merchandising
article.paragraph: The BBC approached Walter Tuckwell, a New Zealand-born entrepreneur who was handling product merchandising for other BBC shows, and asked him to do the same for the Daleks andDoctor Who.Howe (1994), p. 342Tuckwell created a glossy sales brochure that sparked off a Dalek craze, dubbed "Dalekmania" by the press, which peaked in 1965.Howe (1992), p. 137
article.heading: Toys and models
article.paragraph: File:1966Dalek.JPGthumbrightA Louis Marx & Co. Dalek modelThe first Dalek toys were released in 1965 as part of the "Dalekmania" craze.Howe (2003), pp. 475483These included battery-operated,friction driveand "Rolykins" Daleks fromLouis Marx and CompanyLouis Marx & Co., as well as models from Cherilea, Herts Plastic Moulders Ltd and Cowan, de Groot Ltd, and "Bendy" Daleks made by Newfeld Ltd.At the height of the Daleks' popularity, in addition to toy replicas, there were Dalek board games and activity sets, slide projectors for children and even Dalek playsuits made from PVC.Howe (1992), pp. 137152Collectible cards, stickers, toy guns, music singles, punching bags and many other items were also produced in this period.Dalek toys released in the 1970s included a new version of Louis Marx's battery-operated Dalek (1974), a "talking Dalek" fromPalitoy(1975) and a Dalek board game (1975) and Dalekaction figure(1977), both fromDenys Fisher.cite bookHoweDavid J.David J. HoweStammersMarkMark StammersWalkerStephen JamesStephen James WalkerDoctor Who: The Seventies1994paperbackDoctor Who Books, an imprint of [[Virgin Publishing]]London168–1700-86369-871-9From 1988 to 2002,Dapolreleased a line of Dalek toys in conjunction with itsDoctor Whoaction figure series.Howe (2003), pp. 469473, 490491

In 1984, Sevans Models released a self-assembly model kit for a one-fifth scale Dalek, whichDoctor WhohistorianDavid J. HoweDavid Howehas described as "the most accurate model of a Dalek ever to be released".Howe (1996a), p. 159Comet Miniaturesreleased two Dalek self-assembly model kits in the 1990s.Howe (2003), p. 366

In 1992, Bally released aDoctor Who (pinball)Doctor Who pinball machinewhich prominently featured the Daleks both as a primary playfield feature and as a motorised toy in the topper.cite webhttp://www.ipdb.org/machine.cgi?gidInternet Pinball Machine Database: Midway 'Doctor Who'Ipdb.org4 November 199211 October 2011
Bluebird Toysproduced a Dalek-themedDoctor Whoplayset in 1998.Howe (2003), p. 491

Beginning in 2000, Product Enterprise (who later operated under the names "Iconic Replicas" and "Sixteen 12 Collectibles") produced various Dalek toys. These includednowrapone-inch (2.5 cm)Dalek "Rolykins" (based on the Louis Marx toy from 1965); push-along "talking"nowrap7-inch (17.8 cm)Daleks;nowrap2½-inch (6.4 cm)Dalek "Rollamatics" with a pull back and release mechanism; and anowrapone-foot (30.5 cm)remote control Dalek.Howe (2003), pp. 492496

In 2005Character Optionswas granted the "Master Toy License" for the revivedDoctor Whoseries, including the Daleks.Howe (2006), p.123Their product lines have includednowrap5-inch (12.7 cm)static/push-along and radio controlled Daleks, radio controllednowrap12-inch (30.5 cm)versions and radio controllednowrap18-inch (45.7 cm)/ 1:3 scale variants.Howe (2006), pp. 91, 92, 94The 12-inch remote control Dalek won the 2005 award for Best Electronic Toy of the Year from theToy Retailers Association.Some versions of the 18-inch model included semi-autonomous and voice command-features.cite journalHoweDavid J.David J. Howe9 January 2008Voice Interactive Dalek[[Doctor Who Magazine]]390391[[Panini Comics]][[Royal Tunbridge Wells, Kent|Royal Tunbridge Wells]], Kent0957-9818In 2008, the company acquired a license to producenowrap5-inch (12.7 cm)Daleks of the various "classic series" variants.cite journalSangsterJim7 January 2009Action figure toy range[[Doctor Who Magazine]]40358–59[[Panini Comics]][[Royal Tunbridge Wells, Kent|Royal Tunbridge Wells]], Kent0957-9818
cite journalSangsterJim6 January 2010Action figure toy range[[Doctor Who Magazine]]41674–75[[Panini Comics]][[Royal Tunbridge Wells, Kent|Royal Tunbridge Wells]], Kent0957-9818For the fifth revived series, both Ironside (Post-Time war Daleks in camouflage khaki), Drone (new, red) and, later, Strategist Daleks (new, blue) were released as both RC Infrared Battle Daleks and action figures.
article.heading: Video games
article.paragraph:
LicensedDoctor Whogames featuring Daleks include 1984'sThe Key to Time, a text adventure game for theSinclair ZX Spectrum.cite journalPriceRichardDecember 1984Have Tardis will travel[[Sinclair User]]3338[[EMAP]]London0262-5458http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag14 January 2010Daleks also appeared in minor roles or as thinly disguised versions in other, minor games throughout the 80s, but did not feature as central adversaries in a licensed game until 1992, when Admiral Software publishedDalek Attack.cite webhttp://www.bingegamer.net/2009/greatest-games-youve-never-played-dalek-attack/Greatest Games You’ve Never Played: Dalek AttackWalkerJames8 July 2009Binge Gamer16 January 2010The game allowed the player to play various Doctors or companions, running them through several environments to defeat the Daleks.cite webhttp://www.mobygames.com/game/dalek-attackDalek AttackStrykerB.L.SmithMartin[[MobyGames]]16 January 2010
cite webhttp://www.abandonia.com/en/games/1017/Dalek+Attack.htmlDalek AttackSebatianos[[Abandonia]]16 January 2010
cite journalJonathanNashJuly 1993Doctor Who: Dalek Attack[[Your Sinclair]]918–9[[Future Publishing]][[Bath, Somerset|Bath]]http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag14 January 20100269-6983In 1997 the BBC released aPersonal computerPCgame entitledDestiny of the Doctorswhich also featured the Daleks, among other adversaries.cite journalGillattGary22 October 1997The game's up![[Doctor Who Magazine]]257p. 27

Unauthorized games featuring Daleks continued to appear through the 1990s and 2000s, including Dalek-basedmod (computer gaming)modificationsofDark Forces,Quake (video game)Quake, andHalf-Life (video game)Half-Life, and even more recently, a mod ofHalo: Combat Evolved; many of these can be found online, including anAdobe Flashgame,Dalek:Dissolution Earth.cite webhttp://www.ludodoesjudo.com/dalek.htmlDalek: Dissolution Earth24 March 2010[[Adobe Flash]]yeshttps://web.archive.org/20100103085852/http://ludodoesjudo.com:80/dalek.html3 January 2010In 1998QWho, amod (computer gaming)modificationforQuake, featured the Daleks as adversaries. This also formed the basis ofTimeQuake, a total conversion written in 2000 which included otherDoctor Whomonsters such asSontarans.cite webhttp://www.otranto.demon.co.uk/timequake/Doctor Who – Timequake24 March 2010WilliamsGilesChristian DarkinConrad Feinson11 August 2000Another unauthorised game isDalekTron, a based onRobotron: 2084written to coincide with the 2005 series.cite webhttp://www.dalektron.org/DalekTron24 March 2010BowerAndyJames Bower20 September 2007

One authorised online game isThe Last Dalek, aAdobe FlashFlashgame created by New Media Collective for the BBC. It is based on the 2005 episode "Dalek" and can be played at the official BBCDoctor Whowebsite.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/games/lastdalek/index.shtmlThe Last Dalek24 March 2010[[Adobe Flash]]BBC ''Doctor Who'' websiteBBC Newsyeshttps://web.archive.org/20100107013218/http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/doctorwho/games/lastdalek/index.shtml7 January 2010TheDoctor Whowebsite also features another game,Daleks vs Cybermen(also known asCyber Troop Control Interface), based on the 2006 episode "Doomsday"; in this game, the player controls troops of Cybermen which must fight Daleks as well asTorchwood Institutemembers.cite webhttp://www.bbc.co.uk/doctorwho/games/game13/index.shtmlCyber Troop Control Interface24 March 2010[[Adobe Flash]]BBC ''Doctor Who'' websiteBBC Newsyeshttps://web.archive.org/20100205183636/http://www.bbc.co.uk:80/doctorwho/games/game13/index.shtml5 February 2010

On 5 June 2010, the BBC released the first of four official computer games on its website, 'Doctor Who: The Adventure Games', which are intended as part of the official TV series adventures. In the first of these, 'The City of the Daleks', the Doctor in his 11th incarnation and Amy Pond must stop the Daleks re-writing time and reviving Skaro, their homeland.
They also appear in theNintendo DSandWiigamesDoctor Who: Evacuation EarthandDoctor Who: Return to Earth.

Several Daleks appear in theIOS (Apple)iOSgameDoctor Who: The Mazes of TimeThe Mazes of TimeRelease of Mazes of Time http://doctorwhotv.co.uk/doctor-who-mazes-of-time-out-now-12916.htmas rare enemies the player faces, appearing only in the first and final levels.

The robot model883in the gameParadroidfor theCommodore 64looks like a Dalek. The game was later ported to other platforms, and severalfree softwareclones have been developed since, among themFreedroid Classic. Based on this game is aDiablo (series)Diablostyle role-playing game calledFreedroid RPGwhere several Dalek-like robots appear. The base version is calledDalex, its powerful, but slow weapon, theExterminator, is also available to the player.
article.heading: Full-size reproductions
article.paragraph:
Dalek fans have been building life-size reproduction Daleks for many years.cite webhttp://www.dalekcity.co.uk/The DBG HistoryDandoMark2005Dalek Builders' Guild9 March 2010
cite webhttp://www.projectdalek.co.uk/files/dalek_showcase.htmlDalek ShowcaseProject Dalek9 March 2010The BBC and Terry Nation estate officially disapprove of self-built Daleks, but usually intervene only if attempts are made to trade unlicensed Daleks and Dalek components commercially, or if it is considered that actual or intended use may damage the BBC's reputation or the Doctor Who/Dalek brand.cite webhttp://www.daleklinks.co.uk/about/fan-built-daleksThe BBC's position on fan-built DaleksLabrowPeter2010Dalek Links9 March 2010yeshttps://web.archive.org/20090914131540/http://www.daleklinks.co.uk:80/about/fan-built-daleks14 September 2009TheCrewe, Cheshire-based company "This Planet Earth" is the only business which has been licensed by the BBC and the Terry Nation Estate to produce full-size TV Dalek replicas, and byStudioCanalCanal+ Image UK Ltd.to produce full size Movie Dalek replicas commercially.cite webhttp://www.theregister.co.uk/2005/11/28/dalek_film/BBC pulls plug on Dalek lesbian romp flickHainesLester200524 March 2010[[The Register]]cite webhttp://www.thisplanetearth.co.uk/main/index.htmlHome2010This Planet Earth9 March 2010
